Iranian officials claimed that she hanged herself in prison in [[Hamadan]].[http://www.rferl.org/featuresarticle/2007/11/27bad7ce-e7c1-4116-a1d2-b60171cc9ded.html Iran: Female Doctor's Prison Death Causes Public Outcry] Radio Free Europe / Radio Liberty. Retrieved 5 Sep 2016 * [[Nasser Yeganeh]] (1921–1993); Chief Justice of the Supreme Court. He committed suicide on his boat in the [[United States]].{{cite book|last=Milani|first=Abbas|title=The Persian Sphinx: Amir Abbas Hoveyda and the Riddle of the Iranian Revolution| url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VsCJK-c87oQC&pg=PA154&lpg=PA154&dq=Nasser+Yeganeh&source=bl&ots=C4ckcC_flt&sig=wKhutvJculd-W4ByCxlFodkf85I&hl=en&sa=X&ei=y417T_qeNom90QWG4ryQCQ#v=onepage&q=Nasser%20Yeganeh&f=false|date=2000|page=154|accessdate=5 Sep 2016}} === In the news === == See also == * [[suicide crisis]] == Notes == {{Reflist|group="Note"}} == References == {{reflist|30em}} == Cited texts == ;Books * {{cite book | last=Azar | first=Mahyar | last2=Noohi | first2=Sima | last3=Shafiei | first3=Alireza | title=Suicide | publisher=Arjmand | year=2010 | isbn=964-496-034-3 | url= | ref=harv }} * {{cite book | last=Eslaminasab | first=Ali | last2=Taghvaei | first2=Zahra | title=Suicide Crisis | publisher=Ferdows & Majid | year=1992 | isbn= | url= | ref=harv | accessdate=2016-07-06}} * {{cite book | last=Fooladi | first=Ezzatollah | title=Strategies and Plans of Suicide Prevention with a Focus on Youth and Teenagers | publisher=Fajr-e Andisheh | year=2002 | isbn=964-93963-3-0 | url= | ref=harv | accessdate=}} * {{cite book | last=Headley | first=L.A. | title=Suicide in Asia and the Near East | publisher= University of California Press | year=1983 | isbn=978-0-520-04811-9 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=odweSkcMIwcC&pg=PA238 | ref=harv | accessdate=2016-07-06}} * {{cite book | last=Shneidman | first=E.S. | last2=Leenaars | first2=A.A. | title=Lives and Deaths: Selections from the Works of Edwin S. Shneidman | publisher=Brunner/Mazel | series=Series in death, dying, and bereavement | year=1999 | isbn=978-1-58391-011-5 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AmAOa0C40GQC&pg=PA179 | ref=harv | accessdate=2016-07-06}} ;Journals * {{cite journal |last=Anbari |first= Musa|last2=Bahrami |first2=Ardashir |date=Summer 2010 |title= A review on effects of poverty and violence on suicide rates of Iran |url=http://magiran.com/p824887 |journal= Social issues of Iran|via=Magiran |issue=2 |pages= 1–29 |issn=2008-8973 |language=fa | ref=harv |access-date=5 July 2016}} {{subscription}} * {{cite web | last=Jalili| first=Behrooz | title=Suicide the most urgent, Kids' psychiatry emergency | website=SID.ir | issue=7 | url=http://fa.journals.sid.ir/ViewPaper.aspx?ID=5081 | language=fa | ref=harv | accessdate=2016-07-23}} * {{cite web | last=Shirzad | first=Jalal | last2=Gharrahdaghi | first2=Jaber | title=Review of methods and reasons of lethal suicides referred to the medical jurisprudence organization of Iran in the first half of 2004 | website=SID.ir | volume=13 | issue=347 | url=http://fa.journals.sid.ir/ViewPaper.aspx?ID=75069 | language=fa | ref=harv | accessdate=2016-07-16}} * {{cite journal |last=Zargham Boojeni|first= Ali|last2=Yazdani|first2=Mohsen|last3=Yazdan-Nik|first3= Ahmad-Reza|date=Summer 2001 |title= The relation between parents' behavior types and depression or suicide ideation amongst teenagers |url=http://ensani.ir/fa/content/3115/default.aspx |journal= The Medical Journal of Shahr-e Kord University|via=Ensani.ir|issue=3 |pages= 46–54 |issn= |language=fa | ref=harv |access-date=4 August 2016}} {{subscription}} {{Suicide navbox}} [[Category:Suicide by country]]

revision.text:
[[File:UffeRavnskov.png|thumb|right|Uffe Ravnskov (circa 2005)]] '''Uffe Ravnskov''' (born 1934) is a [[Denmark|Danish]] medical doctor, independent researcher, a member of various international scientific organisations, and a former assistant professor and medical practitioner in Denmark and Sweden. In recent years he has gained notoriety for questioning the [[scientific consensus]] regarding the [[lipid hypothesis|Lipid Hypothesis]].
==Early career== He was born in [[Copenhagen]], [[Denmark]], and received his medical doctorate from the [[University of Copenhagen]] in 1961. Over the following seven years, he worked at various [[surgery|surgical]], [[X-ray|roentgenological]], [[Neurology|neurological]], [[pediatrics|paediatric]] and medical departments in Denmark and Sweden. He then began scientific studies at the Departments of [[Nephrology]] and [[Clinical Chemistry]] at the [[Lund University|Lund University Hospital]] in [[Lund]], Sweden. He was awarded his doctorate of philosophy (specialising in internal medicine and nephrology) there in 1973, and was [[professor|assistant professor]] at the university's Department of Nephrology from 1975 to 1979.<ref>Uffe Ravnskov, ''The Cholesterol Myths'', (Washington DC, 2003), p. 307. {{ISBN|0-9670897-0-0}}.</ref><ref>{{cite web|title = ''The Cholesterol Myths'': About the Author|work = www.ravnskov.nu Website|url = http://www.ravnskov.nu/uffe.htm|accessdate = 2006-12-20}}</ref><ref name="Uffe Ravnskov: My life and my work">{{cite web|title = Uffe Ravnskov: My life and my work|work = www.ravnskov.nu Website|url = http://www.ravnskov.nu/lifeandwork.htm|accessdate = 2006-12-20}}</ref>
An encounter with scientific fraud committed by a colleague ended up changing Ravnskov's career: {{cquote|In 1977 I discovered that one of my co-workers had falsified part of his PhD thesis. Whistle blowers are not welcome in the academic world. So, instead of excluding the fraudulent researcher it was my research that was questioned. Finally I found the resistance from my superiors intolerable and decided to go into private practice.<ref name="healthmyths.net">{{cite web|title = Uffe Ravnskov MD, PhD (2005 Interview)|work = Health Myths Publishing Website|url = http://www.healthmyths.net/uffe.html|accessdate = 2006-12-20|deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070109000247/http://www.healthmyths.net/uffe.html|archivedate = 2007-01-09|df = }}</ref>}}
Ravnskov entered private medical practice as a specialist in internal medicine and nephrology in 1979, and worked in Lund in this capacity and as a family doctor until retiring in 2000. Since 1979 he has worked as an independent scientific researcher and since 2000 continues to do so on a full-time basis.<ref name="Uffe Ravnskov: My life and my work"/>
He resides in Lund, Sweden.
==Research in Nephrology== In his 1973 PhD. thesis, ''On Renal Handling of Serum Proteins'', Ravnskov introduced the [[Serum albumin|albumin]]/[[Creatinine clearance|creatinine]] [[Renal clearance ratio|clearance ratio]], a more accurate way to measure [[proteinuria]].<ref>Ravnskov U., "On renal handling of plasma proteins", ''[[Scandinavian Journal of Urology and Nephrology]]'' 1973; 7 (suppl 20) (Thesis).</ref> He was also the first to describe the peritubular uptake of low-molecular-weight proteins.<ref name="Uffe Ravnskov: My life and my work"/><ref>Ravnskov U., Johansson B.G., Göthlin J., "Renal extraction of β2-microglobulin", ''[[Scandinavian Journal of Clinical and Laboratory Investigation]]'' 1972; 30: 71-75.</ref><ref>Ravnskov U., and Karatson A., "Renal handling of human β2-microglobulin in the rat: The importance of sham-operation", ''[[Acta Physiologica Scandinavica]]'' 1975; 94: 467-471.</ref><ref>Ravnskov U., "Serum β2-microglobulin and glomerular function", ''[[New England Journal of Medicine]]'' 1976;294:611.</ref>
He also proposed a [[theory]] that [[glomerulonephritis]] is primarily a tubulointerstitial disease, supported by his earlier findings that most patients with glomerulonephritis excrete large amounts of tubular proteins<ref>Johansson B.G., Ravnskov U., "The serum level and urinary excretion of a 2-microglobulin, β2-microglobulin and lysozyme in renal disease", ''[[Scandinavian Journal of Urology and Nephrology]]'' 1972; 6: 249-56.</ref> and tubulospecific enzymes.<ref>Hultberg B., Ravnskov U., "The excretion of N-acetyl-β-glucosaminidase in glomerulonephritis", ''[[Clinical Nephrology]]'' 1981; 15: 33-8.</ref>
In experimental studies he demonstrated that the handling of proteins by the [[kidney]]s differs in man and other mammals,<ref>Ravnskov U., Johansson B.G., Ljunger L., "Proteinuria in pigs with experimentally induced renal damage", ''[[Contributions to Nephrology]]'' 1975; 1: 50-61.</ref><ref>Ravnskov U., Johansson B.G., "Isolation and partial characterization of a porcine low molecular weight protein occurring in plasma and urine", ''[[International Journal of Biochemistry]]'' 1976; 7: 579-583.</ref> implying that knowledge from animal studies cannot be applied to humans.
Ravnskov also conducted work on [[Urinary system|urinary tract]] infections; in one study of urinary tract infections in women he found that the major cause of [[dysuria]] was soap, not bacteria.<ref>Ravnskov U., "Soap is the major cause of dysuria", ''[[The Lancet]]'' 1983; 1: 1027-8.</ref><ref>Ravnskov U., "Dysuri kan orsakas av tvål", ''[[Läkartidningen]]'' 1985; 82: 836.</ref><ref>Ravnskov U., "Dysuri skyldes som regel sæbe", ''[[Ugeskrift for Læger]]'' 1985; 147: 1493-94.</ref><ref>Ravnskov U., "Sæbe og dysuri", ''[[Ugeskrift for Læger]]'' 1985; 147: 2093.</ref>
His major research interest concerns the association between [[hydrocarbon]] exposure and glomerulonephritis; this interest was sparked by a 1975 paper in ''[[The Lancet]]'' by Stephen W. Zimmerman, K. Groehler, and G.J. Beirne,<ref>Zimmerman S.W., Groehler K., Beirne G.J., "[https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&db=PubMed&list_uids=51959&dopt=Abstract Hydrocarbon exposure and chronic glomerulonephritis]", ''[[The Lancet]]'' 1975 Aug 2;2(7927):199-201.</ref> who found that the large majority of their patients with glomerulonephritis on [[dialysis]] treatment had prior heavy exposure to industrial [[solvent]]s. In his subsequent work in this area, he was the first to demonstrate that a discontinuation of hydrocarbon exposure may improve the course of glomerulonephritis,<ref>Ravnskov U., "Influence of hydrocarbon exposure on the course of glomerulonephritis", ''[[Nephron]]'' 1986; 42: 156-160.</ref> a finding confirmed by follow-up studies made by British researchers.
==Investigation of the Lipid Hypothesis, or "Diet-Heart" Idea== When the lipid hypothesis came to be promoted strongly in Sweden Ravnskov felt there was an incongruity between the [[lipid hypothesis|Diet-Heart Idea]] and scientific literature he could recall. In Ravnskov's words,
{{cquote|When the [[cholesterol]] campaign was introduced in Sweden in 1989, I was very surprised. Having followed the scientific literature about cholesterol and [[cardiovascular disease]] superficially for a number of years, I could not recall any study showing that high cholesterol was dangerous to the heart or the blood vessels, or that any type of dietary fat was more beneficial or harmful than another one. I became curious and started to read more systematically.<ref>Uffe Ravnskov, ''The Cholesterol Myths'', (Washington DC, 2003), p. xv (Author's Forward).</ref>}}
He reexamined data from past scientific studies, and came to the conclusion that the scientific foundations of the Diet-Heart Idea were scientifically flawed, with what he characterized as all the "inaccuracies, misinterpretations, exaggerations and misleading quotations in this research area."<ref>Uffe Ravnskov, ''The Cholesterol Myths'', (Washington DC, 2003), p. xv. (Author's Forward).</ref> His book ''Kolesterolmyten'' ("The Cholesterol Myths") was subsequently published in Sweden in 1991 and in [[Finland]] in 1992. It received adverse attention from the local media when they consulted the researchers and health authorities that it criticised; in the 2003 edition of the book, Ravnskov recalls how it was belittled in a television programme on [[Yleisradio|Finland's Channel 2 television station]] and a copy of the book literally [[Book burning|set on fire]].
With the popularisation of the internet in the late 1990s, Ravnskov saw the opportunity to publicize his conclusion and, in 1997, published selected sections of ''The Cholesterol Myths'' on the [[world wide web]]. According to the search engine [[directhit.com|Direct Hit]] (since acquired by [[Ask.com]] in 1999),<ref>{{cite web|title = About Ask.com: Webmasters|work = Ask.com Website|url = http://sp.ask.com/en/docs/about/webmasters.shtml|accessdate = 2006-12-20|deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20061219194546/http://sp.ask.com/en/docs/about/webmasters.shtml|archivedate = 2006-12-19|df = }}</ref> Ravnskov's website soon became ranked as one of the top ten most popular websites about cholesterol. As a result of this worldwide interest, his book was translated into [[English language|English]] and published in the [[United States]] as ''The Cholesterol Myths: Exposing the Fallacy that Saturated Fat and Cholesterol cause Heart Disease'' in September 2000 by a publishing house established by the head of the [[Weston A. Price Foundation]], [[Sally Fallon]]. It was later published in [[Germany]] in 2002 under the title ''Mythos Cholesterin. Die zehn größten Irrtümer'' ("Cholesterol Myth: The Ten Biggest Errors").
Since 1990, Ravnskov has published over 80 scientific papers critical of the Diet-Heart Idea, proposing new hypotheses and also contending<ref>Ravnskov U., "Quotation bias in reviews of the diet-heart idea", ''[[Journal of Clinical Epidemiology]]'' 1995; 48: 713-9.</ref><ref>Ravnskov U., "Debatt i Science: Kostråd mot hjärtinfarkt försvaras med felcitat", ''[[Läkartidningen]]'' 2002; 99: 2673.</ref><ref>Ravnskov U., Allan C., Atrens D., Enig M.G., Groves B., Kaufman J., Kroneld R., Rosch P.J., Rosenman R., Werkö L., Nielsen J.V., Wilske J., Worm N., "Studies of dietary fat and heart disease", ''[[Science (journal)|Science]]'' 2002; 295: 1464-5.</ref> that "the successful dissemination of the diet-heart idea is due to authors systematically ignoring or misquoting discordant (contradictory) studies".<ref name="Uffe Ravnskov: My life and my work"/> He was the first to suggest that the positive effect of the [[statin]]s may be due to other effects than cholesterol-lowering.
==Awards and Organisations== Ravnskov has received the [[Petr Skrabanek|Skrabanek]] Award in 1999 from [[Trinity College, Dublin]], [[Ireland]], for original contributions in the field of medical scepticism.
He is a member of the free panel of the Journal of the Swedish Medical Association (the [[medical journal]] ''[[Läkartidningen]]''), the [[International Science Oversight Board]], the [http://www.issfal.org/ International Society for the Study of Fatty Acids and Lipids], and is the spokesman for THINCS, [[The International Network of Cholesterol Skeptics]].
==Selected publications==
*''The Cholesterol Myths: Exposing the Fallacy that Saturated Fat and Cholesterol Cause Heart Disease'' (2000) *''Fat and Cholesterol are Good for You'' (2009)
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==External links== *[http://www.ravnskov.nu Uffe Ravnskov Website] *[http://www.thincs.org/ The International Network of Cholesterol Skeptics] *[http://www.issfal.org International Society for the Study of Fatty Acids and Lipids] *[http://www.conem.org/people/ravnskovbio Biography on the website of the Council for Nutritional and Environmental Medicine]
{{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ravnskov, Uffe}}
[[Category:1934 births]] [[Category:Danish scientists]] [[Category:High-fat diet advocates]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Nutritionists]] [[Category:Swedish nephrologists]]

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta2)
revision.text:
{{infobox Economist | name = Victor R. Fuchs | image_name = | image_size = | birth_date = 1924 | institution = [[Stanford University]] | field = [[Health economics]] | alma_mater = [[Columbia University]] (Ph.D.)(M.A.)
[[New York University]] (B.S.) | contributions = | repec_prefix = e | repec_id = pfu157 }} '''Victor Robert Fuchs''' (born 1924) is an American [[health economist]]. He has been called "the dean of health economists" by ''New York Times'' economics columnist [[David Leonhardt]].{{ cite news | last = Leonhardt | first = David | title = Real Choice? It’s Off Limits in Health Bills | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2009/08/26/business/economy/26leonhardt.html | work = The New York Times | date = 25 August 2009 }} ==Career== He is the Henry J. Kaiser, Jr. Professor at Stanford University, emeritus.[http://healthpolicy.stanford.edu/people/victorrfuchs/ Victor R. Fuchs, Stanford University] Since 1962, he has been a research associate at the National Bureau of Economic Research and is the co-director of the FRESH-Thinking Project, CASBS, at Stanford University.{{Cite web |url=http://www.fresh-thinking.org/ |title=Fresh Thinking Project |access-date=2009-07-29 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090125095919/http://fresh-thinking.org/ |archive-date=2009-01-25 |dead-url=yes |df= }} Fuchs was elected to the [[American Academy of Arts and Sciences]] in 1982,[https://www.amacad.org/multimedia/pdfs/classlist.pdf List of active members by class], October 24, 2014 and to the [[American Philosophical Society]] in 1990. In 1995, he served as president of the [[American Economic Association]].{{cite web | title = Honors | url = http://www.aeaweb.org/honors_awards/officerspast.php | publisher = [[American Economic Association]]}} ==Comparison of healthcare in Canada and US== Also, Fuchs published a paper, with James S. Hahn, in the ''[[New England Journal of Medicine]]'' "How Does Canada Do it? – A comparison of Expenditures for Physicians' Services in the United States and Canada." It discusses the differences in the Canadian and US healthcare spending patterns and also discusses why healthcare expenditures are so much higher in the United States. They found that the higher US expenditures were entirely based on 234% higher fees for services than Canada even though there are more physicians per capita in Canada. That shows that the typical view of Canada saving money by delivering fewer services is false and that the insurance setup, being a [[single-payer system]], is what gives it the edge.{{cite journal | last1 = Fuchs | first1 = Victor | last2 = Hahn | first2 = James S. | title = How does Canada do it? – A comparison of expenditures for physicians' services in the United States and Canada | journal = [[The New England Journal of Medicine]] | volume = 323 | issue = 13 | pages = 884–890 | doi = 10.1056/NEJM199009273231306 | date = 27 September 1990 | url = http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJM199009273231306#t=article }} Differences between the United States and Canada on fees, spending, and use are shown. The accentuating difference begins with the disparity in health care coverage. Canada operates under a universal health care system, which covers majority of their residents. On the other hand, the United States operates under a fragmented multi-payer system that fails to provide coverage for many Americans.{{ cite news | title = Comparing international health care systems | work = PBS Newshour | publisher = PBS | url = https://www.pbs.org/newshour/updates/health-july-dec09-insurance_10-06 | date = October 6, 2009 }} Moreover, the lack of correspondence between both countries regarding health care coverage validates part of the narrative reported in the study, which concluded that the US spent more on physicians' services than Canada. Canada provides more services at lower costs by virtue of negotiated physician fees between physician organizations and the provincial governments as well as other limits placed on spending.{{cite book | last1 = Folland | first1 = Sherman | last2 = Goodman | first2 = Allen C. | last3 = Stano | first3 = Miron | title = The economics of health and health care | publisher = Pearson Education | location = Essex, England | year = 2014 | edition = 7th | isbn = 9781292020518}} Furthermore, the study also suggests that higher expenditures in the US is a function of many factors including higher wages earned by US physicians, the difference of physicians on demand, billing costs, quality of health care, physicians' workload, and superfluous amenities. Notably, the factors bring to question the underlying differences in health care delivery, and the authors reported more general practitioners in Canada per capita. The limited role of general practitioners in the US compared to Canada may imply that Canadian physicians are "more inclined to recommend additional evaluation and management services." The lower quantity of physician services per capita coupled with higher expenditures is an example of the fundamental inefficiencies embedded within the fragmented multipayer health care system in the US. Thus, a concerted effort to reform these inefficiencies has been made by the US government, which resulted in the adoption of the [[Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act]], a noteworthy addition to the health care system since the passage of both Medicare and Medicaid in 1965. The advent of the key legislation is shifting the payment of care in the US from the inefficiencies of fee-for-service to payment models grounded on improved outcomes and lower health care spending.{{cite news | last = Cameron | first = David | title = Moving beyond health care's fee-for-service | work = Harvard Gazette | date = July 11, 2012 | url = http://news.harvard.edu/gazette/story/2012/07/moving-beyond-health-cares-fee-for-service/ }} Specifically, some of the models reduce costs through a team-based approach known as a [[medical home]], which are often led by a general practitioner. Furthermore, Congress is currently working on a "permanent doc fix" to control Medicare spending on physician services, also known as the [[Medicare Sustainable Growth Rate]] (SGR).{{cite news | last = Kliff | first = Sarah | title = The Doc-fix is in: Congress actually has a plan to overhaul doctor payments |date = February 7, 2014 | work = [[The Washington Post]] |url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/wonkblog/wp/2014/02/07/the-doc-fix-is-in-congress-actually-has-a-plan-to-overhaul-doctor-payments}} Since the article's publication, important changes in health care policy have taken place, with the potential to resolve the exorbitant expenditures for physicians' services in the US. ==Books== Fuchs is the author of several books including ''Who Shall Live? Health, Economics, and Social Choice'''{{cite book |last=Fuchs |first=Victor R. |authorlink=Victor R. Fuchs |date=1975 |title=Who Shall Live? Health, Economics, and Social Choice | isbn=978-9814354882}} and ''The Future of Health Policy''.{{cite book |last=Fuchs |first=Victor R. |authorlink=Victor R. Fuchs |date=1998 |title=The Future of Health Policy | isbn=978-0674338265}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} == External links == * [https://www.nber.org/authors/victor_fuchs Papers by Victor Fuchs], held at the [[National Bureau of Economic Research]] {{Presidents of the American Economic Association}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Fuchs, Victor}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Labor economists]] [[Category:1924 births]] [[Category:Health economists]] [[Category:Columbia University alumni]] [[Category:New York University alumni]] [[Category:Stanford University Department of Economics faculty]] [[Category:Fellows of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences]] [[Category:Members of the American Philosophical Society]] [[Category:Presidents of the American Economic Association]] [[Category:Distinguished Fellows of the American Economic Association]]

revision.comment: Updated information on affiliations and key people, as well as correcting the full name in the info panel.
revision.text:
{{Infobox Union|<!-- Please include all unused fields for future use. See [[template talk:Infobox Union]] for usage. --> |name= WSNA |country= [[United States]] |affiliation= [[Washington State Labor Council]], [[AFL-CIO]] |members= 16,000+ |full_name= Washington State Nurses Association |native_name= |image= |founded= 1908 |current= |head= [[American Nurses Association]] |dissolved_date= |dissolved_state= |merged_into= |office= [[Seattle, Washington]], United States |people= Jan Bussert, BSN, RN, president |website= [http://www.wsna.org/ www.wsna.org] |footnotes= }}
'' For the [[Memphis, Tennessee]] radio station previously carrying the calls '''WSNA''', please see [[WLFP]].''
Founded in 1908, the '''Washington State Nurses Association''' (WSNA) is the professional organization representing more than 16,000 registered [[nurses]] in the [[U.S. state]] of [[Washington (U.S. state)|Washington]]. WSNA is a constituent organization of the [[American Nurses Association]] (ANA) and is affiliated with ANA, [[American Federation of Teachers|AFT Healthcare]] and the [[AFL-CIO]].
Jan Bussert, BSN, [[Registered nurse|RN]], is the President of the Association.
== Primary mission == WSNA advocates for the improvement of health standards and availability of quality [[health care]] for all people; promotes high standards for the [[nursing]] profession; and advances the professional and economic development of [[nurses]].
== Publications == *[http://www.wsna.org/Washington-Nurse/ ''The Washington Nurse'']
== Washington State Nurses Foundation == This foundation was established in 1982 to provide awards, grants, and scholarships to support the advancement of nursing in Washington State.
== WSNA Political Action Committee (PAC) == The WSNA-PAC is the nonpartisan political action committee of the WSNA. Established in 1972, WSNA-PAC was one of the first state Nurses-PACs in the country. The PAC's activities include educating and assisting nurses for political action, identifying and supporting nurse candidates for elected state office, raising funds, and interviewing and endorsing candidates for state office who are supportive of nursing issues.
==See also== *[[Labor unions in the United States]] *[[Labour movement]] *[[List of nursing organizations]]
==Archives== * [http://digital.lib.washington.edu/findingaids/view?docId=WashingtonStateNursesAssociation1385_1559_1807_1937.xml Washington State Nurses Association Records.] 1911-1980. 77.45 cubic feet. *[http://digital.lib.washington.edu/findingaids/view?docId=KingCountyNursesAssociationKingCountyWash3049.xml King County Nurses Association Records.] 1908-1990. 35.39 cubic feet.
== External links == *[http://www.wsna.org Washington State Nurses Association] *[http://www.wsna.org/washingtonnurse ''The Washington Nurse'']
[[Category:Nursing organizations in the United States]] [[Category:Medicine and healthcare trade unions]]
[[Category:Trade unions established in 1908]] [[Category:1908 establishments in Washington (state)]] [[Category:Trade unions in Washington (state)]] [[Category:Medical and health organizations based in Washington (state)]]

revision.text:
''This article has been written in 2007. Please feel free to update this article.''
{| style="width: 25em; font-size: 90%; text-align: left;" class="infobox" |- !align="center" bgcolor="lightblue" colspan="2"|<big>[[Paraguay]]: Water and Sanitation</big> |- | colspan="2" style="text-align:center" | [[Image:Flag of Paraguay.svg|100px]] |- !align="center" bgcolor="lightblue" colspan="3"|Data |- !align="left" valign="top"|Water coverage (broad definition) |valign="top"| 99% |- !align="left" valign="top"|Sanitation coverage (broad definition) |valign="top"| 94% |- !align="left" valign="top"|Continuity of supply (%) |valign="top"| n/a |- !align="left" valign="top"|Average urban water use (l/c/d) |valign="top"| n/a |- !align="left" valign="top"|Average urban water tariff (US$/m3) |valign="top"| n/a |- !align="left" valign="top"|Share of household metering |valign="top"| n/a |- !align="left" valign="top"|Annual investment in WSS |valign="top"| n/a |- !align="left" valign="top"|Share of self-financing by utilities |valign="top"| Urban: Nil; Rural: 60% user contribution |- !align="left" valign="top"|Share of tax-financing |valign="top"| n/a |- !align="left" valign="top"|Share of external financing |valign="top"| n/a |- !align="center" bgcolor="lightblue" colspan="3"|Institutions |- !align="left" valign="top"|Decentralization to municipalities |valign="top"| None |- !align="left" valign="top"|National water and sanitation company |valign="top"| Yes |- !align="left" valign="top"|Water and sanitation regulator |valign="top"| Yes |- !align="left" valign="top"|Responsibility for policy setting |valign="top"| Ministry of Public Works and Communications |- !align="left" valign="top"|Sector law |valign="top"| Yes |- !align="left" valign="top"|Number of urban service providers |valign="top"| 1 large public, 500 small private |- !align="left" valign="top"|Number of rural service providers |valign="top"| 2,500 |- |} Despite many years of concerted efforts and achievements in expanding coverage and improving service sustainability, many issues remain to be addressed in the '''[[water]]''' and '''[[sanitation]]''' sector. Key issues include: (i) a low level of coverage for both water and sanitation, in particular in rural areas; (ii) a low level of cost recovery, despite a legal obligation for tariffs to recover costs; and (iii) an institutional framework that is only partially effective.
== Access == While coverage levels in urban areas are high using a broad definition of services, the coverage with higher levels of services (house taps and sewers) remains low compared to demand and to other countries in the region.
'''Water and sanitation coverage in Paraguay (2004)''' {| class="wikitable" |- ! ! ! Urban (58% of the population) ! Rural (42% of the population) ! Total |- | Water | Broad definition | 99% | 68% | 86% |- | | Household connections | 82% | 25% | 58% |- | Sanitation | Broad definition | 94% | 61% | 80% |- | | Sewerage | 16% | 0% | 9% |} ''Source'': [[WHO]]/[[UNICEF]] Joint Monitoring Program ([http://www.wssinfo.org/en/welcome.html JMP]/2006). Data for [http://www.wssinfo.org/pdf/country/PRY_wat.pdf water] and [http://www.wssinfo.org/pdf/country/PRY_san.pdf sanitation] based on Permanent Housing Survey of the [http://www.dgeec.gov.py/Censos/index.php Census] (2002).
== Recent developments ==
In April 2007 a seminar organized by the Center of Multidisciplinary Entrepreneurial Training (CAEM)-TECMA S.A. and financed by the [[Inter-American Development Bank|IDB]] concluded that the Juntas need to improve their management and improve collection of outstanding bills in order to avoid institutional collapse. Otherwise a “domino effect” could occur and jeopardize the financial stability of SENASA as well as the country’s commitments to the World Bank.<ref>[http://www.abc.com.py/ ABC Color]</ref>
== Responsibility for water supply and sanitation == [[Image:Paraguay-CIA WFB Map.png|thumb|300px|right]]
=== Policy and regulation === [[Image:Chaco Boreal Paraguay.jpg|thumb|right|300px|View of El Chaco]] Responsibility for policy formulation is nominally vested in the Ministry of Public Works and Communications and regulation is entrusted to an autonomous entity, the [http://www.erssan.gov.py/ Regulatory Agency for Sanitation (ERSSAN)]. The institutional framework is codified in Law 1614/00 of 2000 establishing a regulatory and tariff framework for the sector. The law, which created ERSSAN, was drafted with the expectation that private sector participation in the sector would substantially increase, which did not occur.
In practice, the Ministry of Public Works and Communications has not developed sector policies, leaving a vacuum in this important area. The regulatory agency, created for the purpose of regulating prospective private enterprises, has been ineffective at regulating the national public enterprise ESSAP. SENASA also faces many challenges, since it does not have sufficient capacity to provide adequate support to the ever-increasing number of Juntas.
=== Service provision ===
Responsibility for water and sanitation service provision in [[Paraguay]] in urban areas rests primarily with a national public enterprise, and with more than 1,621 community-managed water associations (Juntas de Saneamiento) in small cities and in rural areas.
The national enterprise, the Empresa de Servicios Sanitarios de Paraguay (ESSAP), is responsible for serving communities with populations of more than 10,000 inhabitants. In rural communities and small towns with less than 10,000 inhabitants water associations provide services, while technical assistance and financing are provided by the [http://www.senasa.gov.py/ National Environmental Sanitation Service (SENASA)].
The Juntas are grouped in 10 associations which supply water to more than half of country’s population<ref>[http://www.abc.com.py/ ABC Color]: "Juntas de saneamiento deben mejorar gerenciamiento local para no colapsar." 12 de Abril de 2007</ref> The first Juntas were created with the assistance of the World Bank’s first rural water and sanitation loan to Paraguay in 1977, fostering a successful long-term partnership that endures until today.
An interesting phenomenon in [[Paraguay]] is the emergence of independent private suppliers, called “aguateros”, since the 1970s. Their efforts account for a significant share of the expansion of urban water coverage in the area of the capital. Aguateros are private, informal service providers who operate small-scale systems with up to 3,000 connections. An estimated 500 private suppliers serve some total of about 500,000 people.
== Tariffs and cost recovery ==
=== Urban areas ===
Urban utility tariffs are set below cost recovery levels and are adjusted infrequently, leading to substantial operating losses by the national water and sanitation enterprise. This makes it impossible to finance the investments necessary to further expand coverage and to improve service quality.
Tariffs by Aguateros fully recover costs and compare favorably with tariffs charged by the public sector. These tariffs are not regulated, but to some extent controlled by competition between aguateros serving neighboring areas.
=== Rural areas ===
Unlike in many other countries, local Juntas are well organized and do not only recover operating and maintenance costs, but also expand their systems using their own resources and repay a portion of capital costs to the national treasury.
=== Affordability ===
According to data collected by the [[Pan-American Health Organization]] based on multi-purpose household surveys, the share of water expenditures in household expenditures in urban areas of Paraguay was the lowest among 10 countries in Latin America and the Caribbean in the late 1990s. The share was on average 1.4% and 1.7% for urban households in the poorest income decile, showing an unusually low difference between the average and poor households.<ref>[http://www.scielosp.org/scielo.php?script=sci_arttext&pid=S1020-49892002000500013&lng=en&nrm=iso&tlng=en Rangel et al., Public Health 11(5/6), 2002] and especially [http://www.scielosp.org/img/fbpe/rpsp/v11n5-6/10723t3.gif Table on Household Expenditure]</ref> These shares are actually the same or even higher in rural areas, reflecting the unusual high levels of cost recovery in rural areas in Paraguay. Rural households spend on average 1.2% on water, and households in the poorest decile in rural areas spend 2.3% on water. Therefore, despite high levels of cost recovery, tariffs apparently remain affordable.
== External support ==
=== World Bank === As mentioned above, the [[World Bank]]’s relationship with the Government of Paraguay and the SENASA on rural water systems goes back for about 30 years. It spans three successfully completed rural water projects: the [http://web.worldbank.org/external/projects/main?pagePK=64283627&piPK=73230&theSitePK=40941&menuPK=228424&Projectid=P007867 First], [http://web.worldbank.org/external/projects/main?pagePK=64283627&piPK=73230&theSitePK=40941&menuPK=228424&Projectid=P007874 Second], and [http://web.worldbank.org/external/projects/main?pagePK=64283627&piPK=73230&theSitePK=40941&menuPK=228424&Projectid=P007920 Third Rural Water Supply and Sanitation Projects] (approved on December 13, 1977, June 16, 1981, and September 10, 1992, respectively). As a result, the Bank is one of the institutions most trusted by the Government to assist it in this sector. From 1997 to 2007 the Bank supported the US$ 55.7 million [http://web.worldbank.org/external/projects/main?pagePK=64283627&piPK=73230&theSitePK=40941&menuPK=228424&Projectid=P039983 Fourth Rural Water Supply and Sanitation Project] (approved on August 28, 1997), which aimed at increasing water supply and sanitation coverage in rural areas. A secondary development objective was to modify SENASA’s role in the sector from an implementer of projects to an efficiently managed promoter of activities.
The [[World Bank]] has also supported a pilot project to expand services in small towns by providing subsidies on a competitive basis, which involve “aguateros” as service providers. This experience is summarized in the note entitled Output-Based Aid in Water – Lessons in Implementation from a pilot in Paraguay.<ref>[http://rru.worldbank.org/documents/publicpolicyjournal/270-water-paraguay.pdf Output-Based Aid in Water - Lessons in Implementation from a Pilot in Paraguay]</ref>
On April 14, 2009, the World Bank approved a $64 million loan for the [http://web.worldbank.org/external/projects/main?pagePK=64283627&piPK=73230&theSitePK=40941&menuPK=228424&Projectid=P095235 Paraguay Water and Sanitation Sector Modernization Project]. The objective of the project is to increase the efficiency, coverage, and sustainability of water supply and sanitation services in Paraguay by (a) improving the governance of the sector, (b) improving water services and increasing access to sewerage services in the Asunción metropolitan area, and (c) increasing access to sustainable water and sanitation services in rural areas.
=== Interamerican Development Bank ===
In 2001 the IDB approved a US$12m loan to support a [http://www.iadb.org/projects/Project.cfm?project=PR0118&Language=English Small Community Water Supply Sanitation Project] executed by SENASA. Until 2007 more than US$7m had been disbursed.
==See also== *[[Health in Paraguay]]
== References == {{reflist}}
== Sources == * [http://www.erssan.gov.py/ ERSSAN] * [http://www.senasa.gov.py/ SENASA] * [http://web.worldbank.org/external/projects/main?pagePK=64283627&piPK=73230&theSitePK=40941&menuPK=228424&Projectid=P039983 World Bank Rural Water and Sanitation Project] * [http://search.iadb.org/search.asp?Querytext=paraguay+water&ServerKey=Primary&collection=newcoll&language=English&ResultTemplate=default.hts&ResultStyle=normal IDB Water and Sanitation Projects]

{{Infobox building | name = White Cross, Inc. | native_name = | native_name_lang = | former_names = Quezon Preventorium | alternate_names = La Cruz Blanco | status = Orphanage | image = White Cross Orphanage 6.JPG | image_alt = | image_size = | caption = | map_type = | map_alt = | map_caption = | relief = | altitude = | building_type = | architectural_style = Art Deco | structural_system = | material = | cost = | ren_cost = | client = | owner = | current_tenants = children 0-6 years old | landlord = | location = | address = 276 Santolan Road, [[San Juan, Metro Manila]] | location_town = | location_country = [[Philippines]] | coordinates = {{coord|14.604589|121.034764|display=inline}} | groundbreaking_date = | start_date = 1936 | completion_date = | opened_date = | inauguration_date = 10 September 1938 | relocated_date = | renovation_date = | closing_date = | demolition_date = | destruction_date = | height = | diameter = | circumference = | architectural = | tip = | antenna_spire = | roof = | top_floor = | observatory = | other_dimensions = | floor_count = | floor_area = | seating_type = | seating_capacity = | elevator_count = | grounds_area = | architect = [[Pablo Antonio]] | architecture_firm = | structural_engineer = | services_engineer = | civil_engineer = | other_designers = | quantity_surveyor = | main_contractor = | awards = | designations = National Artist for Architecture | ren_architect = | ren_firm = | ren_str_engineer = | ren_serv_engineer = | ren_civ_engineer = | ren_oth_designers = | ren_qty_surveyor = | ren_awards = | rooms = | parking = | url = | embedded = | references = }}
'''White Cross Orphanage''' is a child caring agency in [[San Juan, Metro Manila|San Juan]], [[Philippines]] that provides temporary shelter for children, who are 0–6 years old. Accredited by the [[Department of Social Welfare and Development]] ([[DSWD]]), it gives refuge to children of unwed mothers, indigent families, [[tuberculosis]] patients, mentally or physically-incapacitated parents, prisoners, or victims of incest or rape.<ref name=WhiteCross>{{cite web |url = http://www.dot.com.ph/whitecross/ |title = White Cross |last = |first = |publisher = |date = |website = White Cross |accessdate= 19 May 2014 }}</ref> These children are provided with medical assistance, educational care, and financial support to help them in their early years.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.aidphilippines.com/2011/06/21/white-cross-childrens-home/|title = White Cross Children’s Home |last = |first = |publisher = Aid Philippines |date = 21 June 2011 |website = Aid Phlippines |accessdate= 19 May 2014 }}</ref> [[File:White Cross Orphanage 11.JPG|thumb|The front white cross structure is also the building's driveway.]]
==History==
===Early Beginnings=== In the early 20th century when there was an outbreak of tuberculosis (TB) in the Philippines, the orphanage was established to shelter the children of the TB patients of the Quezon Institute. It was founded by Victoria Lopez de Araneta in 1936.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://showbizandstyle.inquirer.net/lifestyle/lifestyle/view/20070423-61854/White-Cross-lady-honored |title = White Cross Lady Honored |last = Agbayani |first = Claire |publisher = Philippine Daily Inquirer |date = 23 April 2007 |website = Inquirer.net |accessdate= 21 May 2014 }}</ref> Its founding board members include Mercedes McMicking, Conrado Dayrit, Emmanuel J. Dymek, Teodoro Evangelista, Mrs. Carl Hess, Manuel Mañosa, Vincente Marasigan, Paulino Miranda Sampedro, Gonzalo Puyat, Juan Tuason, and Soledad Zulueta.<ref name=PhilStar>{{cite web |url = http://www.philstar.com/education-and-home/678234/home-every-child-story-white-cross|title = A Home for Every Child: The Story of White Cross |last = |first = |publisher = Philippine Star |date = 21 April 2011 |website = Philstar.com |accessdate= 21 May 2014 }}</ref> [[File:White Cross Orphanage 5.JPG|thumb|The name "Quezon Preventorium" is still visible at the facade.]]
Through the leadership of de Araneta, the board purchased the land in Santolan, San Juan, which is four-hectare lot, where the structure would be built.<ref name=PDI>{{cite web |url = http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/inquirerheadlines/metro/view/20070305-52902/Orphanage_marks_founder%92s_100th_year_ |title = Orphanage Marks Founder’s 100th Year |last = Morelos |first = Miko |publisher = Philippine Daily Inquirer |date = 5 March 2007 |website = Inquirer.net |accessdate= 21 May 2014 }}</ref> One of its recognized supporters at that time was President Manuel Quezon and in his honor the orphanage was also known as the Quezon Preventorium. He signed a bill that allowed a portion of horse race revenues to be channeled to the orphanage.<ref name=PDI />
In 1938, two years after its initial operations, the institution was run under the care of the [[Daughters of Charity of Saint Vincent de Paul]] who took in 20 children of TB patients as its wards. The nuns managed the orphanage until they turned it over to the current board in 2004.<ref name=PDI />
===World War II=== On 20 June 1944, during the time of World War II, the Japanese took over the orphanage and the nuns transferred the children to Welfareville in Mandaluyong for safety. Although the board gave Sr. Consuelo Muró, then overseer of White Cross, the authority to close down the institution, she continued the mission and fed the children in its temporary home in Welfareville. When the war ended and through the help of the American liberation forces, they restored White Cross and the children and the staff returned to San Juan in 1946.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://via.library.depaul.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?filename=15&article=1016&context=vincentian_ebooks&type=additional |title = Vincentians in the Philippines: 1862-1962 |last = dela Goza |first = Rolando |publisher = Congregación de la Misión en Filipina |date = 1985 |website = http://via.library.depaul.edu/vincentian_ebooks/13/ |accessdate= 21 May 2014 }}</ref>
==Architecture== [[File:White Cross Orphanage 9.JPG|thumb|Relief of children at play.]] The services of architect [[Pablo Antonio]], who was later recognized as National Artist for Architecture, was obtained to design White Cross, which was aimed to be a fresh-air shelter for the children of TB patients. The building was an Art Deco design with its façade shaped like a large white cross. The bas-relief of children at play that was designed by Italian sculptor Francesco Monti softened the linear and sharp structure of the façade.<ref name=Design>{{cite web |url = http://services.inquirer.net/mobile/07/09/04/html_output/xmlhtml/20070902-86206-xml.html |title = Harvest of Culture and Design Books |last = Villalon |first = Augusto |publisher = Philippine Daily Inquirer |date = 2 September 2007 |website = Inquirer.net |accessdate= 21 May 2014 }}</ref>
Among Antonio’s works, which included the [[Far Eastern University]] (FEU), Ideal Garden, Orchid Garden Hotel, and Syquia Apartments, only the Manila Polo Club and White Cross remain as the stalwarts because most of his designs have been demolished or in a state of decline.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://businessmirror.com.ph/index.php/en/lifestyle/life/20108-an-architect-s-abode |title = An Architect’s Abode |last = Ciriaco |first = Nico Erle |publisher = Business Mirror |date = 30 September 2013 |website = BusinessMirror.com.ph |accessdate= 21 May 2014 }}</ref>
